content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, and high school dropouts from the class of 2004 will cost the nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. High school dropouts from the class of 2004 will cost the Nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. Only 52 percent of students in the 50 largest cities in the United States graduate from high school, falling below the national average of 70 percent. A high school dropout earns about $260,000 less than a high school graduate over a lifetime, and $1,000,000 less than a college graduate. (6) High school dropouts earn significantly less than high school and college graduates over a lifetime. (7) A large percentage of prison inmates have not completed high school, and increasing the high school completion rate could save the US billions annually in reduced crime costs. (8) A study shows that increasing the male high school graduation rate would lead to lower arrest rates. According to a recent study, a 10% increase in male high school graduation rates could significantly reduce arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources for nonprofit organizations to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration, especially among minorities, and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. The Act aims to provide resources for nonprofit organizations to prevent youth incarceration and prepare them for economic self-sufficiency through job training and support services. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for out-of-school youth and those involved in the criminal justice system in urban areas, to help them access education or employment opportunities. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for out-of-school youth and those involved in the criminal justice system in urban areas, to help them access education or employment opportunities. The program focuses on conducting outreach and serving eligible youth through a national network of community-based affiliates, providing a holistic approach for preparing them for employment or education leading to employment, and preventing disproportionate incarceration of youth in urban communities. The section defines key terms such as "community-based affiliate" as a local organization affiliated with a national intermediary, "eligible youth" as individuals aged 18-24 not in school or involved in the criminal justice system, and "national intermediary" as a national nonprofit organization with a network of affiliates. An 'intermediary' is a national nonprofit organization with an affiliate network in at least 50 urban communities, expertise in youth outreach and workforce activities, and 20+ years of operation in 25 states. 'Recidivism' refers to a tendency to return to criminal behavior. The Urban Jobs Program defines terms like recidivism and unsubsidized job, and authorizes grants for the program. The Urban Jobs Program authorizes grants for national intermediaries to provide comprehensive services to eligible youth in urban communities, aiming to create pathways to employment or education leading to employment. To receive a grant under this program, a national intermediary must submit an application with specified details to the Secretary. This includes a request for the grant amount and how it will be used to support participants. The national intermediary must describe how they will use the grant funds to support participants in the Urban Jobs Program, focusing on goals such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, literacy, and numeracy. The national intermediary must describe the underlying supports for the Urban Jobs Program, including engaged community partners. The national intermediary must describe the underlying supports for the Urban Jobs Program, including engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and demonstrated understanding of youth characteristics to enable program participants to achieve outcomes. The Urban Jobs Program aims to create caring relationships with peers and staff, set goals for employment, education, and industry certifications. The curr_chunk focuses on the development of workplace skills, community contribution through service or volunteerism, and preparation for higher education or industry certifications. The curr_chunk highlights the importance of volunteerism, development of 21st-century workplace skills, sense of responsibility for one's future, goal-setting strategies, reduction of risk-taking behaviors, and achievement of improvement. The curr_chunk describes the activities to be provided through the Urban Jobs Program, focusing on reducing risk-taking behaviors, improving educational outcomes, enhancing employment outcomes, reducing recidivism. The Urban Jobs Program aims to provide activities leading to industry-recognized certificates or credentials. Eligible activities include case management and a comprehensive set of services. The Urban Jobs Program offers a comprehensive set of services including case management and educational services such as skill assessment, remediation, and preparation for high school equivalency. Services also connect to career pathways with opportunities for industry-recognized certificates. The Urban Jobs Program offers services like skill assessment, preparation for high school equivalency, and connection to career pathways for industry-recognized certificates, job readiness activities, and support services. The Urban Jobs Program provides training, personal development, unsubsidized jobs, support services like health, nutrition, substance abuse counseling, housing assistance, and transportation. The Secretary of Labor creates the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee with 11 members from the private sector. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector, employers in high-impact industries, a national intermediary staff member, and representatives from the Department of Labor. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members including private sector employers, representatives from high-impact industries, a national intermediary staff member, and Department of Labor representatives. Members serve for the life of the Committee, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and duties include analyzing and preparing recommendations for the Secretary. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members including private sector employers, representatives from high-impact industries, a national intermediary staff member, and Department of Labor representatives. Members serve for the life of the Committee, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and duties include analyzing and preparing recommendations for the Secretary concerning the design, operation, and long-term strategic priorities of the program under this section, as well as the formulation and application of guidelines related to program activities. The Committee also prepares and submits periodic reports to the Secretary. The Committee members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing services for the Secretary. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of Committee members and detail government employees to the Committee without reimbursement, interruption, or loss of civil service status or privilege. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Committee.
